div.head: Etymology
div.p: אֱמוּנָ֖הemunah: from Heb.אָמַן aman and this from the rootא-מ-ן: to confirm, to bear. Whence alsoאֱמוּנִים emunim (trustworthy), אָמֵֽן amen (so be it) and אֱמֶ֔ת emet (steadfastness, faithfulness, truth). Cognates: Ancient Greek:ἀμήν(amḗn), Latin: āmēn

div.head: Testimonies
div.p: Alonso Schonkel's Hebrew dictionary distinguishes the following senses for the Hebrew word אֱמוּנָ֖ה, emunah:
"Faithfulness", loyalty to a person or charge. Marital in Hos 2.22, social in 2Chr 19.9, to God in Eccl 45.4.
"Truthfulness", when referring to words, i.e. "speaking faithfully" (Jer 5.1; 7.28; 9.2; Ps 119.86; Pro 12.22).
"Act well," when referring to conduct, i.e., "act faithfully" (Ps 37.3 and 119.30), sometimes referring to acting well in an economic sense (2Ki 12.16; 22.7; Pro 28.20).
As God's predicate: "faithful", "loyal", "just", "righteous" (Deut 32.4; Is 25.1; Ps 89.2.3.25.34.50; Ps 96.13 and 40.11).
In the physical sense: "steadfastness", i.e. "faithfulness in the hands", in the only case where it is found that they were to be held up until sunset (Ex 17.12).
As an adverbial form: "faithfully", "loyally", "sincerely" (2Ki 12.16; 22.7; Is 59.4; Ps 33.4).
As a causative phrase: "for trusting" God (Hab 2.4).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The conceptual change did not occur with the translation from Hebrew into Greek in the Bible of the Seventy. The translators of the LXX used in 31 passages the word πίστις or a derivative to translate emunah. On fewer occasions they used aletheia,"truth". They also translated on multiple occasions אֱמֶת, emet, by πίστις. St. Jerome, when translating his Vulgate from the Hebrew and Greek, always corrected the translators of the LXX in the cases of אֱמֶת, emet, by using veritas, while on quite a few occasions when they used aletheia to translate emunah, he corrected them by resorting to fides. In short, the translators of the LXX did not distinguish between אֱמוּנָה, emunah, which was closer to pistis or fides, and אֱמֶת, emot, which was closer to aletheia or veritas. This is a first cause of the conceptual shift, since the scribes of the Church of Rome who wrote the Letter to the Hebrews and Clement's Letter to the Corinthians were familiar with the wording of the Old Testament in Hebrew and Greek and were influenced by this conceptual confusion.

Now why did the author of the Letter to the Hebrews give πίστις this meaning instead of resorting to the Greek word for "belief", δόξα? In our opinion, because δόξα has a less dogmatic meaning, more akin to a simple opinion. Ancient religious thought admitted diversity of opinion when it came to questions such as the immortality of the soul (with Sadducees and Epicureans denying it, as opposed to Pharisees and Platonists, among others, affirming it; not that this meant that Sadducees and Epicureans did not believe in the existence of God or gods). Nor was the verb νομίζω, "to believe", useful, because it had reflexive overtones, such as "to consider" or "to think", which did not fit in well with the dogmatic thinking that was being tried to impose. On the other hand, πίστις could be used as the hif'il of the verb אָמַן, aman, "to confirm", because it meant "to believe" but firmly, with total certainty, or in other words, not admitting other opinions. T his kind of dogmatic thinking was emerging at the same time in the Pharisaic or rabbinical synagogues and in the Christian churches. It is no coincidence that at the same time as the Letter to the Hebrews was being written, the Sanhedrin of Yamnia promulgated the Birkat Ha Minim, or Benediction Against Heretics, ordered by Gamaliel II and formulated by Rabbi Samuel, by which Sadducees, Nazarenes and, in general, all heretics were excluded from the rabbinical synagogues. The Christian concept of heresy emerged at the beginning of the 2nd century in the Letters of Ignatius of Antioch and was developed in the second half of that century by Irenaeus of Lyon. The faith thus became a dogmatic way of thinking which did not admit diversity of opinion and which condemned the heretic or heterodox, at first, to excommunication (the herem of the rabbis, but not the biblical herem) and, later, acted violently against them.
